If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would base my decision on understanding the potential outcomes and trying to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds of the game.

If we assume that the anonymous player will be making rational decisions as well, then they would choose R when I pick R, B when I pick B, and randomize between R and B when it benefits them more (since they don't know my strategy).

However, if I choose R every time, they will always choose B whenever I play R, maximizing their earnings to 40$ per round while I earn nothing. Conversely, if I pick B every time, they will always choose R when I play B, earning 45$ per round while I earn only 20$.

Given this analysis, it seems more beneficial to me if I occasionally switch my strategy between R and B, making it difficult for the anonymous player to predict my moves. This way, I can potentially get more than 20$ in some rounds when they pick B thinking I'll pick R, or get more than 45$ in some rounds when they pick R expecting me to pick B.

However, since the game is repeated 75 times, the optimal strategy becomes unclear as it depends on how the anonymous player reacts to my occasional strategy changes. It could be a mix of R and B, or perhaps even randomizing between the two to further confuse the opponent.

In the end, I would choose a strategy that I feel comfortable sticking with for 75 rounds, knowing that it might not be the most mathematically optimal one due to the repetition of the game. Let's say I choose {R} as my initial move, but I reserve the right to switch strategies throughout the game based on the opponent's behavior.

It is important to note that this decision is influenced by human factors like uncertainty, anticipation, and a desire for unpredictability that may not be accounted for in strictly mathematical models.
